Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: This morning, my phone buzzes with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” It’s our weekly ritual, a time to catch up and reassure them I’m doing well in the city. I know how much they look forward to these calls—Mom always asks about my job, Dad wants to hear about my friends. But today, I also remember that I left my driver’s license at home last week, and tomorrow is Election Day. The only time I can swing by my apartment to grab my ID is this morning, before work. If I miss this window, I won’t be able to vote. My parents expect to hear my voice, to feel included in my life, but my civic duty demands I make this detour. I stare at my phone, torn between dialing their number and rushing out the door. My heart pounds with guilt and anxiety, knowing I can’t be in two places at once, and that whatever I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
